key_insight: Spatio-temporal alignment for end-to-end 3D perception should combine explicit motion priors with attention-based semantic alignment, rather than relying on attention alone or an oversimplified unified physical model.
problem_solved: Addresses unreliable cross-frame alignment in end-to-end 3D perception for autonomous driving, where attention-only approaches and simplistic motion models lose structural and textural priors needed for stable temporal modeling.
method: Diagnose limitations of attention-only alignment and of using a single simplified physical motion model across scenes.
Introduce a hybrid spatio-temporal alignment strategy that fuses explicit motion priors (physical/kinematic cues) with attention-driven semantic feature matching.
Integrate the hybrid alignment into an end-to-end 3D perception pipeline for autonomous driving and evaluate its effect on temporal consistency and object localization across frames.
impact: Improves temporal robustness and alignment fidelity in E2E 3D perception, helping practitioners build more reliable detection/tracking models for autonomous driving without over-relying on one alignment mechanism.
visual_elements: Side-by-side diagram: attention-only alignment vs. hybrid explicit-motion + attention alignment (arrows showing corrected trajectories).
Sequence visualization: object tracks over multiple frames with and without the proposed alignment to show temporal stability.
Feature heatmaps: before/after alignment showing semantic correspondence and structural preservation.
Flow chart: pipeline integration of the hybrid alignment module within an end-to-end 3D perception model.
paper_title: Rethinking the Spatio-Temporal Alignment of End-to-End 3D Perception
paper_authors: Xiaoyu Li, Peidong Li, Xian Wu, Long Shi, Dedong Liu
